Recognize and manage acute asthma exacerbations in pregnant patients.
Asthma is common in pregnancy and can have serious implications for both mother and child; timely management is crucial.

You are the on-call physician in a labor and delivery unit. A 30-year-old woman, 32 weeks pregnant, presents with wheezing and shortness of breath after running to the hospital due to abdominal cramps.
Management of an asthmatic patient in late pregnancy experiencing an acute exacerbation.
Brightly lit delivery room with monitoring equipment and a birthing bed.
Monitor beeps, overhead announcements, faint voices in the corridor
Pregnant woman in distress at the hospital, with a nurse assisting her.
Oxygen mask, nebulizer, IV fluids, albuterol inhaler
Patient in respiratory distress, history of asthma exacerbations, currently pregnant.
Patient on continuous monitoring for fetal heart rate and maternal vitals.
Monitor and treat, consider admission if unstable.
>2 min without intervention  increased respiratory distress; >5 min  potential fetal compromise.
CT scan of the chest, MRI
Wheezing on auscultation, increased respiratory effort.
Patient in respiratory distress, 32 weeks pregnant.
She was fine until this morning, but she started wheezing as she got here.'
Im having trouble breathing... I cant catch my breath.'

Administer oxygen, assess vitals, start nebulizer treatment.
Initiate IV fluids, consider systemic steroids, call respiratory therapy.
Prepare for possible intubation, escalate monitoring.
